text.0: do homage unto varuṇas and mitras eye offer this solemn worship to the mighty god.
text.1: who seeth far away the ensign born of gods sing praises unto sūrya to the son of dyaus.
text.2: may this my truthful speech guard me on every side wherever heaven and earth and days are spread abroad.
text.3: all else that is in motion finds a place of rest the waters ever flow and ever mounts the sun.
text.4: no godless man from time remotest draws thee down when thou art driving forth with winged dappled steeds.
text.5: one lustre waits upon thee moving to the cast and sūrya thou arisest with a different light.
text.6: o sūrya with the light whereby thou scatterest gloom and with thy ray impellest every moving thing.
text.7: keep far from us all feeble worthless sacrifice and drive away disease and every evil dream.
text.8: sent forth thou guardest well the universes law and in thy wonted way arisest free from wrath.
text.9: when sūrya we address our prayers to thee today may the gods favour this our purpose and desire.
text.10: this invocation these our words may heaven and earth and indra and the waters and the maruts hear.
text.11: neer may we suffer want in presence of the sun and living happy lives may we attain old age.
text.12: cheerful in spirit evermore and keen of sight with store of children free from sickness and from sin.
text.13: longliving may we look o sūrya upon thee uprising day by day thou great as mitra is.
text.14: sūrya may we live long and look upon thee still thee o farseeing one bringing the glorious light.
text.15: the radiant god the spring of joy to every eye as thou art mounting up oer the high shining flood.
text.16: thou by whose lustre all the world of life comes forth and by thy beams again returns unto its rest.
text.17: o sūrya with the golden hair ascend for us day after day still bringing purer innocence.
text.18: bless us with shine bless us with perfect daylight bless us with cold with fervent heat and lustre.
text.19: bestow on us o sūrya varied riches to bless us in our home and when we travel.
text.20: gods to our living creatures of both kinds vouchsafe protection both to bipeds and to quadrupeds.
text.21: that they may drink and eat invigorating food so grant us health and strength and perfect innocence.
text.22: if by some grievous sin we have provoked the gods o deities with the tongue or thoughtlessness of heart.
text.23: that guilt o vasus lay upon the evil one on him who ever leads us into deep distress.
